intro.title: Greetings and How to Introduce yourself
paragraph: In Korean, greetings and introductions are very important. They are not just polite phrases, but play a vital role in maintaining harmony, respect, and social order. One of the key aspects of Korean greetings is that they are highly dependent on age and social hierarchy. How you greet someone reflects your awareness of the other person's age, social status, or position at work.
For example, if someone is older or holds a higher position, you are expected to show more respect in both your greeting and your speech.
speech_levels: Informal - eg. when speaking to friends or younger people (안녕 - annyeong)
Polite - eg. when speaking to strangers or in everyday situations (안녕하세요 - annyeonghaseyo)
Formal - eg. when speaking to elders or in formal situations (안녕하십니까 - annyeonghasimnikka)
paragraph2: This emphasis on social roles is not limited to greetings. It also affects the way you speak in general. These levels are chosen based on the relationship between the speakers. At the A1 level, we will mostly learn the polite form, which is suitable for most everyday situations and respectful enough for use with strangers.
Using informal speech with elders or superiors can be considered rude. Always consider the context and relationship when speaking Korean.
